Cute table and seating arrangements, and you can move together tables as necessary and available. The food is good but very basic. Cheese plate with some fruit and walnuts, salami plate, bread basket with olive oil. 

My issue with this place is the $12 corkage fee for bottles that you buy from their establishment. I understand now that it's a shop too and the wines by the bottle supposedly aren't already marked up for retail, and that explains the extra $12. However, our waiter, instead of explaining this, said, "Um, we have to uncork it." And I said, well, that's true, but typically places don't have corkage fees for wines purchased there and not brought in. And he replied with "Well, we have to uncork it either way so there's a fee." Um, okay. Especially funny since the wine he recommended was a screw top.
author: Rogue R.

description:
One star because:

The dessert wine, "highlighted" on the front page of the menu , was bad

Our server acted like we were bothering his afternoon nap; he didn't acknowledge our orders for at least five seconds before grunting his OK

In the words of Tamara (see 3/16/08 review), "need I say more"?
author: S C.

description: I like this place, a lot. It keeps it simple. Modern, clean decor. Great for Financial District types that may have grown out of the Harrington's type places across the street. Wine, beer, yummy cheese plates and other tasty food to nosh on while you sample different wines or beers. They sell wine by taste, glass or bottle. You can even buy a bottle to go. Which came in handy during the holidays last year while looking for a nice gift for the boss. On my last visit they were so busy, we found a seat along the curve of the velvet couch. Our waiter was really nice. We opted to try Chardonnay. It's starting to get a better rap lately. My friend tried a buttery oak type, I tried a non buttery oak type from a steel barrel that I actually enjoyed. No sasafrass, just simple and clean (like the wine bar!). It was crisp just like our waiter described. He let me try a taste first, and when I decided to order it, brought me a fairly large goblet. I wasn't sure if I'd like it, but it was nice and refreshing and not too fruity as I'd feared.  My friend and I wondered if that was the proper glass for white wine for a split second but who cares? It was a nice night! I'd visit again for sure!
author: Christy L.

description: cozy little place just like an easy stop for your wine tasting!!!
author: cecille p.

description: I adore this place first and foremost because it is so unpretentious (hard to find in this town) and secondly because they always feature an interesting selection from which I've tried many new wines I'd have never tried otherwise. It's where I had my most euphoric un-oaked Chardonnay experience, actually. The service could be better and they could lighten up their bar bites. But this isn't a Michael Mina enterprise, just a lovely little after-work haunt you might find in any town in any part of the country and I guess that's why I like it so much.
author: Sheri E.

description: You know I don't hate this place and have had a fair number of decent wines and reasonably nice after work drinks hours here, but it is just that it could be so much better.  Really - like a lot better.  Let's start with the service.  Words that come to mind are: indifferent, inconsistent and distracted. None of those are good words when associated with service people I think you would agree.  Then there is the atmosphere which as other reviewers have pointed out is very shopping mall store front.  The weird thing is that this is so obviously a shopping mall storefront you would have thought the owners would have *tried* to go with decor choices that juxtaposed that? But no, they went with light wood veneers and industrial tables and lighting - sort of Ikea on steriods.  So the resulting atmosphere is cold and store-like (it IS indeed a store as well, so whatever) and a bit loud and offputting.  The new outdoor seating section is a tremendous improvement as far as I am concerned and maybe will improve the feel of the place.  But all that being said, I am glad it is there because 1) the wines are diverse and interesting if not always knock it out of the park fantastic, and 2) it is a great place to have a glass, some rocking cheeses (did I mention the cool cheese plates - I do like those very much) AND then pick up a bottle to go to the dinner party you are your way too.  A great addition to the Embarcadero Center choices which tend toward the chain restaurant direction and lack any style whatsoever. I would take this place over many of the neighborhood options any day. If they solve the service issues, I would bump this to a 4 star no problem....
author: Kirsten M.

description: Wine is my favorite place to have a glass of wine and relax after a long day. The friendly, knowledgeable staff are spot-on with what they think I'll enjoy so I always let them choose the wine for me. It is a little on the pricey side, but you get what you pay for with the generous pours and fabulous cheese plates. Ask your server to suggest a cheese (or two or three) to pair with your wine and you won't be sorry! The tables are nice for conversation, but if you're alone or in a pair, sit at the bar and learn something you didn't know about wine or join in with the ever-present witty banter between the servers. If you're in a group, sit at the comfy, round loungy table next to the bar and enjoy a little buffer from the noise as the place fills up with the after-work financial district crowd. Don't like the music playing? Tell them what you want to hear and they probably have it no matter how obscure the request. Wine's a great spot. Give it a try and maybe I'll see you there!
author: Jen G.

description: I have been coming here since it opened. It is not perfect, but it has 40 wines by the glass or half glass that changes each week. Other raters here said that it is too small, but it is bigger than most wine bars in San Francisco. 70 people could fit inside and about another 20 outside. It is very nice inside with paintings and usually pleasant music. I have seen people denounce the Press Club for being too big, at 9,000 square feet. "Wine" is at least average size for a San Francisco wine bar. Also, it is near the Embarcadero BART Station, and major bus lines. Also, one gets FREE parking for 4 hours with just a $5 validation which is almost unheard of in San Francisco.
author: Howard S.

description: Ok, my review may be somewhat influenced by the fact that a very big (and somewhat neurotically pushy) group of wine lovers were gathering at this venue the first night I tried it out.  But other patrons notwithstanding, the space is not nearly as warm or inviting (i.e. stay for hours and forget the time/date/year) as the LWB.  They did have a good wine selection and I can't complain about the cheese plate (plus the vegetarian antipasto plate was a welcome and worthy recommendation).  There are some Hayes & Vine flashbacks but it is an alternative for those who want some drinky drink but aren't willing to battle the Royal Exchange/Harrington's happy hour madness.
author: Anjali K.

description: a place for good wine and cheese... i'm somewhat biased, as this place is partially owned by my boyfriend's previous boss (and he was a good boss, which is hard to find). we always enjoy WINE, with it's hayes & vine feeling (another owner is formally of h&v) but without the brightly painted windows and plushy pillows. sometimes the staff is more interested in chatting behind the bar than being attentive to the patrons. and what's with not having backs on some of the seats? when you drink, you really want your lumbar to be supported. otherwise, one drink, two drink, three drink, floor!
author: Bee H.

description: This used to be a fun place to go with knowledgeable staff.  Ever since Greg and Gretchen have left the place is not the same.  The new management is not friendly and they have raised the prices.  The wine selection isn't as good as it used to be.  There are a lot of wine bars in SF that are a better choice (Local Kitchen and Wine Merchant when Carl is working).
author: Heidi H.

description: my friend works here and I like to hang out here while I am in the Bay Area.  The wine and cheese selection is fabulous.  I came here for a glass of vino before I took the GMAT and I think it helped me get an awesome score.  They validate parking for the garage underneath, so this is a great spot to visit if you are driving into SF from the burbs.
author: olivia s.

description: 10 person wait staff and nobody would respond to my frantic waving from the bar.  Finally,a haughty waiter with a frown to match appeared bothered and bewildered.  Wine list was predominantly foreign.My friend and I tried to get a second glass of wine, to no avail.  Getting the check was equally as difficult.  When I asked one of the wait staff (our waiter had since disappeared) for our check (as we were trying to get to a movie), she told me "Relax, this is a wine bar".  Ok, but we still need to pay.  The place caters to private groups tucked behind a short wall  and customers buying wine.  I will not return as there are far superior wine bars in our town.
author: lori f.

description: I have been here a few times after work with friends and each time I am less impressed.  They do have interesting wines and a large number open to taste.  However, the prices are very high.  I guess that is a function of the real estate.  The service is very poor.  Sometimes you can wait 20 minutes just to get the wine list.  Surprised no one else seems to have mentioned this, but in the evenings when the place can get full the noise level is outrageous.  The place is nothing but hard surfaces and the sound bounces around and never stops.
author: Alan R.
